'And then face off with the people outside, and tell them... let them know how mighty we are.' Kemar flips back to the very first flashcard, pressed with a flower of the rainforest. Its power to live is unwavering, and its power to adapt is unrivalled. Rainforest, prairie, or barrens, it will bloom more avidly, more ardently than all.
modules.name: Meaning of Flowers

modules.description:
“午安，女士。我来自梅兰德基金会，您可以称呼我为锡人。接下来，我将会负责这座未来的电影之都——蓝卡坞的建设。”
“天哪，锡人先生，您可真像从电影中走出来的人。”
“自从电影这种娱乐风靡起来之后，这样的评价我每天都要收到至少一次。”
“那您为什么不把这样的评价化为现实呢？我敢说，电影未来一定会是哥伦比亚最流行的娱乐。”
“我会考虑的。不过，我有一个问题，女士。我看到你们带来了许多和蓝卡坞的起点有关的东西，但是，为什么其中会有一个金属探矿器的头部和一段在矿洞中作业的影片？”
“这真是个好问题！您知道吗，先生，我刚入行时，也问了我的前辈同样的问题。而我的前辈告诉我，这件藏品和这段影片，对电影这种艺术的诞生有着相当重要的意义。”
“愿闻其详。”
“您看，接在探矿器上的摄像机不仅记录了矿洞的三维结构，还捕捉到了矿石的光泽以及周围环境的动态变化。据说，这段影像拍摄于建国时期，目的是更高效地勘察地貌，不过，究竟是谁拍摄的已经不可考了。”
“呃......毕竟我也没法告诉别人，当时我为了省事，把这个圆盘直接装在了自己的脑袋上。”
“您说什么？”
“——没什么，只是一点自言自语罢了。女士，我还是没明白，这和电影有什么关系？”
“据说，蓝卡坞的奠基人，就是在拓荒过程中偶然看到了这段影片，并由此意识到——我们的技术原来已经能够做到记录并向他人展示一段生活。于是，他转而开始学习摄影技术，而后在湖边拍出了属于自己的第一部电影。”
“这......恐怕当事人都想不到，工作时留下的影片，居然能制造这样的契机。”
“但是，我想，如果那个人知道自己拍摄的影像还有这样的价值，他一定是欣慰的。”
“为什么您能这么肯定，女士？在我看来，电影和许多当下兴起的娱乐一样，只是一种无意义的消遣行为。”
“我小时候看了人生中的第一部电影，先生，我不知道该怎么形容自己的感受，我只知道——那时起，我就下定决心要参与电影的制作。
“它在您眼中也许只是一种消遣，但在我看来，它给许多人带去理想与希望。我想，电影是一定会凭某种契机诞生的，因为，总会有人渴望以影像的方式向他人分享自己的所见所闻，所思所想。您能说，这种想法是没有意义的吗？”
“......哈。”
“抱歉，我没有否定您的意思——”
“不，女士，或许您是对的。曾经有一个农夫告诉我，用于杀人的技术同样可以用来建造安居之地，我被他说服了。但当那些高楼大厦拔地而起时，一个问题开始困扰我，这就是我所期望的未来的终点了吗？而今天的这场偶遇，您让我看到了一种新的可能性。所以——
“如果我想成为一名演员，我该怎么做？”
modules.name: “颅相学”

modules.description: The man came into the shop just as it started raining. He looked about sixty. Exquisite attire, stern expression, seemingly quite the panache. His satin coat was blotched with water; as Luchino welcomed him in, he helped him remove it with deft, practiced motions. The man looked him over, stared for a few blank seconds, then quickly made his way into the atelier where old Umberto had been waiting. Luchino would never butt in on a client meeting his nonno; he went to hang the coat on the rack instead. It was a finely made coat, sumptuous material, and most importantly, had a polished black portable crossbow in one of its inside pockets. What a big shot this guy must be, Luchino thought to himself. Before long, an argument arose from the atelier. Fragments of speech stole their way through the door's cracks, and slipped into Luchino's ears. '...Luca's stuff... it ends here...' '...you're the one... did it... how could you...' '...Masina... only girl...' Were those my mamma and papà's names? Unable to help his curiosity, Luchino stuck his ear to the atelier wall, but all he caught was the sound of things falling to the floor, and the yelling of that man. '...MY flesh and blood too!' The atelier door burst open, and there the man stood like a wall between him and his nonno. He opened his clenched hand, revealing a silver thumb ring in his palm. 'This was Luca's thumb ring. It's time you took it.' The man offered it to him, the look in his eyes and tone of his words brimming with expectation. Past the man's shoulder, Luchino saw the once-orderly atelier in a state of disarray, fabric bolts and tape measures strewn across the floor, and Umberto shrinking away inside. Luchino had never seen his nonno quite so... weary. He was about to take the ring, but at this moment red-hot rage supplanted all his curiosity. Luchino pushed the man's hand aside, the thumb ring falling onto the rug. 'Who are you? Nonno and I don't accept rude clients.' The man's expectation promptly vanished, and his expression twisted with anger, his eyes shining green. Luchino realized—he and this man had the same eyes. 'You are not welcome at De Montano.' Summoning all his courage, Luchino stood up straight, and repeated himself. 'Please leave.' The order cut straight through the air. Luchino shocked even himself to see his words put out the fury in the man's brow. He sensed a hint of discouragement in the corners of the stranger's familiar eyes, but quickly it was covered back up beneath his solemn mask. '...As you wish, tailor boy. Arrivederci.' The man put his waterlogged coat back on, then took one final look at Luchino. Then, he exited the shop door and vanished into the rainy black of night. 'Nonno, who was that man?' 'A father who'd kill his own daughter. You don't need to know his name. 'He wants to play Siracusan games, he wants to be a big shot. This is the punishment he deserves.'
modules.name: 'The Big Shot'

modules.description:
Evaluation No.: RDLEDSG03
Operator Code Name: Eunectes
Full Name: Zumama
Time Registered: Half a year
......
Participant in:
1. Design, development, component production and assembly of colossal-scale machine 'Raging Ironhide.'
2. Testing, restoration and upgrades of all-new energy emission devices in the training grounds
3. Improved designs for remote-control drone swarm weapon mounting plans.
4. Servicing of Rhodes Island Landship automated navigation systems.
5. Self-researched planning for some machine hyper-remodeling, audited and launched with the Engineering Department.
......
12. Daily maintenance, painting, and emotional communication with and guidance of intelligent operation platform Lancet-2 (note: applied for by Operator herself and not conducted under official Engineering Department authority. Engineering Department does not interfere excessively in light of Lancet-2's behavioral non-rejection of Eunectes).
......
Overall evaluation:
Operator Eunectes has participated in multiple projects and displayed impressive performance in all aspects since joining the Engineering Department, and now tentatively possesses the capacity to research, develop and work independently.
......
Supplement from Officer-in-Charge (directly dictated):
Jeez, do we have to make these evaluations so formal every time? Could be doing WORK here... If someone's my disciple, they're worth educating. She learned how to test microcapacitor unit performance and then straight away, she managed to fumble a whole breadboard together! She's gifted! Really resembles me there! And she's hardworking. Read through every single engineering book the landship has over the past half year, and she finds people to discuss with everywhere. They don't put half of the true might of technology to print, though. She's got a lot more to learn. As for why she's so eager, well, don't ask me. Probably hasn't scooped her jaw up from the floor since she landed on Rhodes Island... She's had two sorta major awakenings in her life, right? First was seeing a nomadic city pass by with her own eyes when she was a kid, second was seeing a talking Lancet-2 in Acahualla. I can see the hopes in her, for machines, for herself. There's a possibility in there... in the not-distant future, I bet she'll be able to build machines with her own two hands that surprise even herself. Maybe her creations will lead Terra in technological innovation. I might just hand my Chief Engineer position to her when the time comes, it's not out of the question... That last one was a joke, don't write it down.

Date: Dec 13
Approver: Closure
modules.name: Zumama's Tool Box

modules.description:
Just what were those massive things sailing across the barrens? Zumama couldn't figure it out, try as she might over three straight sleepless nights.
Gavial saw the heavy bags under Zumama's eyes, and on one hand showed the appropriate concern, while the other hand was clenched in a fist as unreserved as ever. Zumama crashed to the floor, but showed no hurry to get back up.
'Old Man Zuluzhak said those things were nomadic cities. What's a nomadic city?' Zumama asked as she stared up at the blue sky, giving her friend the same question that had been bothering her for three whole days. She'd never been this hung up before. Even the mushrooms she'd never seen before growing on trees only lingered on her mind for a day and a half.
Gavial gave an answer she considered incredibly wise, a saying she'd heard from Old Man Zuluzhak. 'It is why it is, and that's why it is.' Then she started pumping her arms. 'You rested enough, Zumama? Let's keep going!'
Zumama suddenly felt a little listless. She got up, and walked off to where the nomadic city had sailed past. Its outline was still faintly visible, but her eyes could see far further than her feet could take her. How could a child's gait ever catch up to a sailing machine? Sunset came, and she felt the distance between her and the nomadic city hadn't narrowed one bit.
She felt somewhat dejected, and gloomily sat on the ground, but bumped against something as she did. From underneath her, she pulled out a strange metallic ring. Zumama had once witnessed the most experienced boy of the tribe show off roughly the same thing. What was it called, again? A short name... a 'nud'? Maybe a 'nup'?
Zumama put it in her pocket. It was likely the thing hadn't even come off the nomadic city—it was just some careless traveler's dropped belonging—but all the same, Zumama loved it, very much.
She began to collect these abandoned and scrapped metal parts, putting them together with no principle whatsoever. At first, she bound them with thread, then stuck them together with glue, until she eventually learned from a passing caravan what welding was.
Finally, one day, this strange little contraption was born from Zumama's hands. Gavial and Tomimi's verdict was 'ugly', but still, she loved it, very much.
She clasped it in her hands, and came to where she once saw that nomadic city. It had long since vanished, but Zumama always had a feeling she could sense the tremors from it as it sailed.
Suddenly, a strange Liberi showed up beside her, and asked, 'What's on your mind there, young lady?'
She tightly gripped the tiny, ugly little thing in her hands, so hard her fingers hurt.
'I want to make it move.'
modules.name: 'The Little Ugly Thing'

modules.description:
In light of special permissions granted, the Field Operations Department has hence passed the following resolution with respect to Eunectes:
Where the entailing mission would fall under Reclamation Algorithm scope, this operator shall be pursuant to tactics of a reinforced nature in meeting the enemy.
In witness whereof,
This badge is hereby conferred upon the above named.
'It's simple. Push the button, and that mountain will be blown to pieces.'
modules.name: Eunectes's Specialized Badge

modules.description: When she went to claim Harvey's remains, some specifically warned her that their rites should be conducted as simply as possible. Continuing to bang on about it all was just further a disgrace to the dead, doing nothing to help the reality. In circumstances like these, one could hardly believe the term 'bereavement pay' ever existed. No one had a snowball's hope of getting anything meaningful out of those lackadaisical officials, at least not for now. So in the end, all the protests earned was a promise—verbal, of course—that they'd end the conflict ASAP and return everyone to work sooner than ASAP, if only every single factory would just shut up and stay that way from now on until the steam engines turn again. 'Believe in Victoria, and after that, go back inside.' Not unexpected, the remaining workers agreed. Still more behind her than were dead, luckily. Catherine was just the one who stepped up precisely when people were hoping for someone with a backbone. She led the lot back into the safety bounds, and wrapped the whole affair up on the spot. The funeral was over just as fast as those negotiations. The way back from church to the workers' residences wasn't any longer than it used to be. Catherine hiked up to the first floor, and just like always, just like that, pulled the door open and went in. Harvey never locked the door. All the workers on the assembly line were brothers and sisters to one another; everyone visited each other whenever they liked. Thick as thieves on the clock, and off it too. But now, Catherine stands as straight as ever in her sitting room. She looks about it. It's all the deathly same; there's still half a jumper sitting on the tea table next to the window. That's Lindy's knitting, at least before Lindy went to the hospital. Then Catherine took over and promptly snapped one needle while not watching what she was doing. She couldn't be arsed to replace it, so she pilfered the thinnest screwdriver out of her toolbox and used that instead. That is why the last two rows have every stitch unworked, leaving only a long succession of yawning holes. Let's finish that first, Catherine mutters to herself as she picks up the jumper, catches sight of what was underneath it, and then freezes. Only a worker could recognize it for what it is at a glance: a scale miniature of a steam engine, built bloody well for being cobbled together from resmelted scrap. Could only be Harvey's work. Right. He always was brilliant at this sort of thing, it hits Catherine. It's obviously just a random thingamajig built by someone with spare time to kill. Nothing valuable about it. No need to treat it like a part of him that's still here, clutching it, weeping long, bitter sobs over him. The phase where their sacrifices were exchanged for concessions was over now. Dressing death up any further than this should be enough to make anyone sick. All that happened here was someone made a decision, and didn't hesitate once about it... and that was that. Catherine puts the jumper down, opens the window, leans over and strikes a match against the heel of her boot. The scent of a cheap cig scatters through the air, floats out of the window, melts into the grimy grey urban scape. Seems I'm not going out for drinks today, she thinks to herself.
modules.name: Leisure Hours

modules.description:
The old prison guard hands Pascuala a bowl of soup. She puts her hand in and fishes out a scrap of saltfin leather with writing scrawled on it: 'Boss, we plan to blow up the maximum security cell block with saltfin poop explosives. We'll rescue you while causing maximum chaos to scare the hell out of these people. That's how we'll keep them under our thumbs and make a fortune!' She nods her head in satisfaction, listening to the guard hum a tune as she waits for tomorrow's jailbreak.
Wait. Something's not right here! Pascuala's eyes widen as she looks at the drafty walls of her cell and the frail old guard with his back turned, humming his tune. This isn't a maximum security cell! She looks out the window. Her crew has already finished planting the explosives, and their shadows are retreating in the moonlight.
Pascuala slams down her soup bowl, 'Hey! You locked me up in the frigging wrong cell!'
The old guard straightens up, shakily, 'What? There's a fire in your cell?'
'No! You put me in the wrong cell! I committed a capital offense. I should be in the supermax.
'Huh? Soup? I just gave you your soup. No need to worry, child. This here's the county jail. I'm sure someone will bail you out tomorrow.'
'No! I'm going to the gallows tomorrow! Look! My wanted posters are all over the walls. I should be in maximum security!'
The old guard squints at the wanted poster. 'No. I'm afraid you're mistaken. This looks nothing like you. She's a fearsome demon, and you're just a frightened little girl.'
'Finshit!' Pascuala jumps three feet in the air. 'I robbed the mayor's house, kidnapped his precious pet musbeast, drained his wine cellar, sold off all his jewels, and threw a wild party in his mansion. The old geezer got so mad he passed out for three whole days! I deserve to be in maximum security!'
'Oh—' The old guard gives her a knowing glance. 'I get it now.'
Pascuala's face glows with joy. Finally, they would transfer her to the right prison cell. Then, tomorrow, when the explosives go off, she would shock the whole town into submission! She would make her fortune with this, and even become the town mayor just for the heck of it!
The old guard pats her on the forehead. 'You poor girl. You must be delirious from your fever. We've got to get you to the medical office, straightaway.'
He rushes her off to see his good friend, the town doctor. 'You poor girl,' the doctor murmurs. 'You've been wrongly arrested and developed a fever from the shock.' He gives her medication to stop the fever, combined with a sedative. He then places her in a warm bed with heart-print sheets. By the time Pascuala drifts off to sleep, she is surrounded by plush toys, with a lollipop in her mouth.
The next day, Pascuala's crew, armed to the teeth with explosives, stand in grim silence around the hospital bed. The doctor places the girl in their arms. He looks them over and yells, 'You must be her family! The girl is so sick! Why didn't you bring her here earlier?!' The crew stares at their 'fearsome' leader, bundled up like a flower bouquet. A collective horrified scream rings through the room. In a panic, they dump Pascuala back onto the bed, turn tail, and bolt into the night, never to return.
—And so, according to legend, the greatest bandit gang in Salt Town history crumbled overnight… at the hands of one old prison guard.
modules.name: Colorful Life in the Salt Flat

modules.description:
迪亚兹今天已经是第三十七次收到这种带着打折章的物件了。
从前几天起，他的店里陆陆续续来了一批特殊的客人，他们会向柜台后递去文件袋，泡面桶盖子，偶尔还有整块金属板材。无一例外地，上面都盖着一个印章，印着被烤串串起的艺术馆。老爹并没有拒绝这些客人，而是按着印章上的优惠信息痛快地给来客打折。
绝大多数这样的来客都会称赞烤肉店的环境，也诧异于印章能将店面的外观复现得那么完美。老爹听到后只会爽朗地笑着，然后开始讲述艺术馆变成烤肉店的过程，接着欣赏客人们惊叹的神情。
客人们自然也会和店主谈起自己是为何而来的，其中大部分人确实是因为推荐而来，据他们讲，比起优惠，宣传者让人一定要来的固执态度才是他们好奇一试的主因。有的人甚至被缠了很久，这个宣传者会软磨硬泡地劝他们拿出东西来盖章。老爹听了不由得摇摇头，说着这孩子还是一点都没变，然后给来客送上一杯免费特饮。
但有些人的经历就略有不同，他们说自己拿到的打折章是一份赔礼。当老爹担忧地询问时，他们却回答说只是一些无关紧要的事。诸如办公室被喷了涂鸦，工程道具蘸上了颜料，或者在夜里例行检查时被巨大木偶吓到了等等。来客们回忆时鲜有抱怨的态度，老爹也笑着一起谈论这些麻烦的制造者，随后再以这个杜林女孩的名义为客人们端上一份特制烤肉。
而今天的客人里，有一位气质明显不同。他身着萨尔贡沙漠部族特有的衣着，递来一块印着章的空白油画布。老爹询问他印章的由来，客人平静地说起他如何在旅途中结识那位会用食物酱料作画的女孩，又如何与她交流画艺，还将女孩绘出的荒野画交给了老爹。而打折章，就是两人初次交换作品时的赠礼。老爹听完安心地舒了口气，他将画作挂在了离柜台最近的地方，并对旅行画家保证一定会提醒女孩与对方保持联系。
凌晨时分，老爹送走了最后一桌客人。他回到自己的住处，马上坐在桌前抽出一张信纸。
“亲爱的特克诺——”
这封信会很长。在提笔写下开头的那一刻，老爹心中就有了预感。
modules.name: 烧烤店官方优惠章

modules.description:
新系列视频企划案（第五版）
时间：1097年5月12日
系列名：
《跟着穆丽儿学习矿石知识》（不行，不够有特色！）
《你真的以为你了解这些矿石吗？》（不对，观众本来就不了解呀！）
《一块矿石多久才算“成年”？》（备选，感觉“成年”这个说法应该有趣一些？）
《一个矿石收藏家在雷姆必拓待了三个月，她身上发生了这样的变化......》（备选，这个梗感觉有点过时了）
《矿石的秘密》（不想想啦！！要不然还是用回我最早的系列视频的名称吧？）
视频内容：介绍挑选好放在柜子里的这一批矿石
视频风格：要有一些综艺感，和探险视频的随性风格做出区分
视频目的：用通俗易懂的方式讲述这批矿石的有关知识
视频时长：控制在10-20分钟（不要每次都说过头！）
视频分段主题：
1.综述（1-3分钟）
简明扼要地介绍本期节目的主旨
2.介绍矿石（5-8分钟）
讲述每块矿石的历史（围绕最抓人的点去设计，把这点呈现出来！不要只是读台本！）
3.讲找到这些矿石的故事（5-8分钟）
剪辑过去探险视频里的片段，配上解说呈现给观众（之前吃了大亏的地方！不要以为介绍视频里自己在做的事很简单，要说得更有趣更生动一些！）
注意事项：
1.不要乱瞟，活跃一些，观众看得出你是不是在念稿。
2.要把观众想象成你的朋友！
3.严格按照计划执行！不要随意更改计划！
4.太难了！我根本不适合做这种事！
5.啊啊啊为什么我非要做这种事不可！为什么我会得矿石病！！
【这里留了一片空白，空白处有着各种涂鸦，其中最显眼的是一块矿石，矿石旁边有几块污渍，像是泪水滴落留下的痕迹。】
6.听着，穆丽儿，我知道你已经失败了好几次，你不想努力了，你眼下只想钻进被窝里大哭一场。但是，你也不想就这样放弃你的一切，不是吗？那就打起精神，做出新的节目，你不是已经决定了吗？你要在城际网络上，继续你的生活。
modules.name: 矿石展览柜

modules.description:
The head porter comes by Xingzhu's door for the third time, and for the third time, she apologizes to him. But in response, he waves his hand and says: 'No need to rush—in your own time.'
With the master of the Ning household gone, there was no reason for the scattered family to return to this old manor, and one after another, they moved their belongings out. They had places to be, and left without so much as a farewell, but Xingzhu still had fond memories of the place and stayed. However, that was only the beginning of the avalanche, as with no employer present, the help also tendered their resignations one by one. Now, she is the only one left in the grandiose manor.
A moving van sits in the courtyard, and the porters consult her on each item they load. Each question brings a pang of reluctance; leaving anything behind feels like abandoning a piece of herself. But if she fills the small studio she rented with the past, how could she begin a new life there? In the end, she chooses only the most important things, and bade the head porter to wait for her at the manor gate.
After the van leaves the courtyard, the silence of the mansion becomes even more unnerving. There is a chill in the air, and Xingzhu draws her clothes tight. She has never seen the manor so messy and deserted, its former treasures now nothing more than junk to stub your toe on, creaking as they are trod upon.
She slowly walks down the corridor to a large pot of lotuses, a creation she and the family gardener once nurtured together. In the past, whenever the Nings hosted a banquet, she loved looking for any excuse to wander the grounds instead. One time, the gardener took her all over the compound, and in the kitchen, they found an exceedingly suitable pot. 'One day, when there's no one left at your side, you'll still have this pot of lotuses,' said the gardener. For countless afternoons, she would sit by the pot as happy as can be, watching the little fins dart about under the lotus leaves. The gardener has gone back to his hometown to look after his granddaughter, and took the fins with him. Only the lotuses are left, and she is at a loss as to where they belong.
She continues onwards, wanting to see the rock garden shaped like a fowlbeast. In her youth, the oddly-shaped rock often found its way into her dreams, always turning into a true blue fowlbeast that took her to the warm place her parents lived. It is only now that she notices the rockery had collapsed, nothing more than a pile of rubble.
She continues onwards: to the old persimmon tree in the garden, the towering bookshelf in the study... So much to leave behind.
......
'Excuse me.'
'Is there something else you wish to take, Miss Ning Yin?'
'Yes... this key.'
The ancient key lies in Xingzhu's palm, the grain on its handle worn away after decades of use.
'Even if you keep it...' The head porter hesitates and looks at her expression for a moment, before finally changing his tone: 'Very well. Nothing wrong with that.'
And so, the old key hangs upon her keychain once more, despite having no use anymore. It jangles alongside the key to her new studio, echoing a lonely melody of the old days that are no more.
modules.name: Farewell to the Old Days

modules.description:
[Visitor Record]
Visitor: Georgia Miltner
Reason for visit: Visiting family
Visiting: Nowell
Department: Medical
Relation: Next of kin

(Miscellaneous noises in room)
You came to little Connie's baby shower a few years ago, right? But Grandma didn't move to Connor County, so it was only last year, after I got that stack of letters that had been piling up during the war that I heard the news.
Yes, it really was... unexpected. The baby, bawling her head off, suddenly opening her eyes wide and flailing her limbs, which got everyone staring at an optician randomly strolling past the garden. Now that I think about it, pretty much anyone would've thought it was some kind of sick joke. Grandpa's great-grandpa, still alive and untouched by time, suddenly reappearing after decades of silence... Ridiculous, really.
There are a lot of strange things out there, so we should've realized your circumstances weren't quite so odd, all things considered.
But you're not here out of curiosity for the family freak, are you?
No, of course not... Great-Grandpa Nowell.
Just Nowell is fine. We're here to chat. No need to get tangled up in formalities.
Mister Nowell.
...Sure. You said you were Madeline's grandson?
That's right, my dad was Grandma Madeline's youngest.
Madeline is also my youngest child... The last time I saw her, your father had just been born. He never met me, and you hadn't either. If it wasn't curiosity that had you so insistent on finding a man you've never met, then what?
Visiting family. Just like I wrote on the form. No more, no less.
(Silence, punctuated by breathing)
Dad wasn't as lucky as I was.
When Grandma became the talk of the town over her insistence on searching for you, to the point that she and Grandpa split, Dad took over in her stead. He was always setting out, then coming back empty-handed. All my memories of him are just his back, coming and going out of the door at the end of the hall. I grew up, Dad got old, and on his sickbed, I vowed to both him and Grandma that I would find you.
...What if you got the wrong man again?
Well, I'm not so sure my kids would want to take over once my legs give out, but I'll tell them the same stories Grandma told me, and let them make their own choice. But I didn't get the wrong man, did I?
You're just like Madeline.
*sigh* You mean my face? Dad said so too, but it's my granddaughter who's a spitting image of her. You don't know what name Grandma Madeline chose for her, do you?
And what name would that be?
Nowell. She's called Nowell. A Gaulish name... and yours, too. Apparently, while tidying up some letters, she found one where you said it was a girl's name in Gaul, so Great-Grandma started calling you it as a joke in the reply—
(Hurried breathing)
(Sound of hands rubbing together)
A-Are you alright, Mister Nowell?
No... No, I've... I've got nothing to do with those letters...
I brought them along. Here. There's a family photo too, along with a letter Dad wrote to you before he passed. I figured you'd want to see.
I...
You've never stopped caring, have you?
modules.name: To Grandpa

modules.description:
《车轮滚滚》第752期
两名运载车驾驶员走进一家酒吧。
其中一个人说：“我今天运气真差，又遇上了劫路匪帮，还好我一把方向盘躲了过去，但我的车身还是被他们刮花了。”
另一个人说：“刮掉一点车漆而已，你就别倒苦水啦。我可是被他们弄坏了两根保险杠呢！”
“两根？”第一个驾驶员问，“他们同时从前后两面夹击你的车子？”
“怎么可能？那样他们也会没命的。”另一个驾驶员重新绑起她的头发，“他们从前面截停了我的车。”
“那怎么会同时弄坏两根保险杠呢？”
“我的防身武器送去修了，只好将后保险杠拆下来，把他们揍了一顿。还好扭送他们到治安官手上让我拿了些奖金，不然那才叫亏大了呢！”

“这么烂的笑话，谁批准刊载的？”顶着黑眼圈的男人往地上啐了一口，顺手把杂志翻过一页。
“别看你那破书了，来活了。”同伙一钢管将杂志打落在地，往男人怀里塞了一捆带刺的铁丝，“老规矩，往前五百米，铺上。”
男人蒙上脏兮兮的面巾，拎起那捆铁丝沿着道路往前走去。
“去他的，我只配来铺第一道关吗？就算扎破轮胎，车子停了，我分到的也是最少的那一份。可要是扎不破轮胎让车子跑了，挨打的总是我！”
男人说着话，手上动作不停，简陋却有效的减速带很快铺满了这段路面。远处尘烟升起，车子来了。
眼眶乌黑的男人看着来车，愣了一下。
那辆运载车看起来破破烂烂的，就连前保险杠都已经摇摇欲坠——将它固定在车头的，是一把巨大无比的管钳。
男人拔腿向着后方的同伙跑去，一边跑一边喊：
“又是她！又是她！
“那个女人又来赚外快了！”
modules.name: “随身保险杠”

modules.description:
“腿伤有恶化，你在安布罗修修道院剧烈活动太多了......太过分了，怎么可以派你去执行这么危险的任务？！”
“当初所有情报都表明那只是最普通的移动修道院接收任务，谁也没想到情况会演变到需要我......站起来的地步。”
“你真没事吗？我是说，除了腿伤之外......你看起来心不在焉的，是安布罗修的经历让你想到什么不好的事情了吗......不行，我一定得去投诉第七厅，简直太过分了！”
“噗。我只是在想，要是在出任务之前就把轮椅设计好，就不会那么费劲啦。不过，多亏了安布罗修的经历，我想通了这台轮椅最后缺失的一点设计哦。要看看吗，设计稿？”
【轮椅定制设计稿】
轮胎：
不用充气式轮胎，用硬质树脂的实心胎。轮椅没法配太厚的轮胎，太薄的充气式轮胎又很容易在荒野上被扎破。听莫斯提马说，拉特兰城航线附近的那个大湖每年春季都有羽兽从伊比利亚海边迁徙过来，应该找个时间“徒轮椅”过去看看。
轮毂：
纠结轮毂该做成什么造型才好看。本来想要左轮弹巢的形状，但总感觉还不太够。
想到了。很早以前不是和小乐研究过，教堂那些华丽的花窗如果旋转起来会是什么模样嘛！虽然没想通怎么让教堂转起来，但至少可以把轮毂做成花窗的形状？
动力系统：
如果申请军用级的动力系统，不知道能不能成......但这台轮椅姑且也要登记成我的办公用车，或许真能成也说不定。那样就可以去参加真正的赛车比赛了。手推圈也要保留，只用手推的话，说不定还能合法地参加自行车比赛？
......
诸如此类的设想罗列了整整十几页，每一页都配有手绘的示意图，偶尔还点缀有潦草的小涂鸦。
“好多......你不会能分身吧，明明一直躺在床上，是什么时候做的这些设计？”
“就是躺在病床上的时候呀。清醒地躺在那里，脑袋里总要想些什么嘛。不过，对操作系统的最后一点补充设计，是我在安布罗修修道院的时候突然冒出来的点子。我想给操作系统加上亮度追踪并自动导航的功能。”
“轮椅在什么场合才能用到亮度追踪啊......？”
“等我彻底康复之后，想在轮椅上摆一盆花，然后让轮椅自己每天追踪着亮度，驮着那盆花去晒太阳。这样，轮椅也能过上有趣的生活。”
modules.name: “弹匣与花窗”

modules.description:
“这个羽毛掸子是哪里来的？”菲亚梅塔抽出鲜红的羽毛掸子不悦地问。
正在擦拭盔甲的帕特里奇昂抬起头回答：“哦，你是说菲菲吗？那是你朋友莫斯提马寄过来的礼物，说你不在的时候我可以睹物思人。”
“你为什么用我小时候的昵称称呼这个羽毛掸子......？”
看见女孩的两条眉毛揪扯在一起打得不可开交，帕特里奇昂迟疑片刻，吞吐道：“大家都觉得像你，我就这么叫了。”
“哪里像了？”女孩举起羽毛掸子，不以为然地抖了抖。
“这毛色和你耳羽的颜色一模一样，还有它们支棱起来的形状，多像你小时候我给你梳的辫子啊。”
“给我丢掉！”
“那可不行，这是别人的一片心意，丢了多不礼貌。”老人将羽毛掸子从女孩手中拿走，重新插在旧头盔上，然后满意地点点头，“就这么插着多好看啊，不然这副盔甲摆在家里孤零零的。”
“那就插几束花上去，或者把你的勋章挂上去！”
“我是多么谦虚的一个人，怎么会把自己的勋章挂出来呢？”
“那你要怎样才肯收起来？！”女孩试图把羽毛掸子抢回来，但几次尝试均被老人不着痕迹地挡回。
“哎，不行，说什么都不行，你不在家都是菲菲陪我。看电影时它可安静了，在一旁从来不会嘀咕什么剧情老套啊角色好蠢啊爆米花太难吃啊。”
和老人四目相对良久，女孩确定无法说服他，无奈地捏了捏额角。
“......好吧，拗不过你，算了。”
闻言，老人露出得逞的笑容，但很快笑容便僵在了嘴角，女孩话锋一转——
“本来我请了一个月的假，打算在家待着好好休息休息，顺便陪陪你。”摇了摇头，女孩叹气道，“既然现在你有菲菲陪着，那我还是出去旅游散散心，不打扰你的清闲生——”
不等女孩讲完，老人迅速拿起羽毛掸子，几步上前拉开储物间的门，随手一丢又立即关上门。
“哎，就是个羽毛掸子，收起来就是了。”
“可它插着很好看啊。”
“哪里好看了？炸着毛长得那么潦草。”
“它不是很安静吗？”
“看电影的时候就该一边吃爆米花一边和旁边的人东拉西扯。”
“不是很像我？”
“嗐，别挤对我这老头子了......”老人揉乱女孩的头发，无奈笑道，“小菲，不是它像你，是我想你，行了吧。”
modules.name: 毛刷套装

modules.description:
那位老者显然想让刚上任的录武官下不来台，舞着扫把便使了一套羽兽点叶，招式之刁钻古怪、千变万化是云青萍前所未见。老者临了又问一句：“有本事拆吗？”在众将士的围观下，云青萍面有愧色：“晚辈力有不逮。”老者嗤之以鼻，低头扫地，不再搭理他。
在询问将士们后，云青萍了解到，这位刁难自己的扫地工与上一任录武官是挚友，两人聊了一辈子的武，对“武”的追求可谓纯粹。云青萍本就担忧自己无法胜任录武官一职，上任第一天还被将了一军。“没有真本事，也配拿起录武簿品评武功？”老者心中想必是这样看待他的。
可那套招式到底要如何拆解？他冥思苦想，得出一法，立时去找老者比划，还欲请路过的将士替他演练，老者却冷声点出他的谬误。
云青萍碰了一鼻子灰，第三日、第四日，但凡想出新法，便去找那位老者讨教。围观此事竟也渐成军中乐事，众人品评着他的解法，为他的巧思喝彩，也在他被老者驳倒时叹息。时日久了，虽一拳未出，云青萍却早已与老者“交手”无数次。
虽一直不得解，云青萍也并未去向老师寻找现成的答案，而是自己翻遍库藏武学典籍，看遍目所能及的武功，终在一日梦中惊起，念着：“我知道了！”他翻开录武簿，那一日的记录特地留了半页空白，他提笔欲写，却又意识到——自己的解法是否真的可行，那位老者才说了算，于是便心急如焚地找他讨教。
“他走了？何时回来？”
将士的目光使云青萍高举着录武簿的手慢慢垂了下来。
那天老者一丢扫把，翻开床板，抄起封存已久的剑，便离开了。将士说，他所图之事必为义，所以并没有人拦着。老者走之前交代，如他回不来，便将陪了他四十年的那把扫把烧给他。而现在早已过了约定的时间。
云青萍坐在院中，依言将老者的扫把烧了，望着火光发愣，身边是围观了这整件事的将士们。
“好一个老头，留下个谜题就跑了。”将士们说，“不如，把你的解法也写下来烧给他吧？”
云青萍的神色却不似刚上任时那般迷茫了。他合上录武簿，将那未完成的一页珍惜地留在了其中。
modules.name: 未完成的录武簿

modules.description:
“喵。”Miss.Christine窝在多利毛茸茸的分身上，懒洋洋地开口，提出了一个她觉得很有意思的提议。
多利第一个附和：“能给那些生活惨兮兮的小家伙带来一些希望，我很愿意参加。”多利又慢悠悠地叮嘱：“只是，你可不要把他们弄哭啊。如果阿黛尔有一天也喝下一瓶在传说中能实现愿望的饮料，我希望那个梦境是温暖的。”
“嚯！给你的贩卖机小游戏准备礼物！那我最新研发的家伙‘大丑二代机’可得带上！没人会不喜欢！嘎哈哈哈！”
Miss.Christine闭上眼甩了甩尾巴，仿佛这样就能把大祭司发出的吵闹声音从身边甩走。
“就我们几个？不再多叫几个，比如那些——”
“喵！”
“哦哦，好吧，哈哈哈！你还是不愿意叫上那群蠢狼，就因为几百年前他们聚在一起吵架时踩到了你的尾巴？还好那次我护住了我的宝贝限量版唱片！”
“喵——！”
“好好好我不该提的，尊敬的女士。为表歉意我可以给你快递来一些小玩意，就当是惊喜。”
“喵~”

几日后。
一个对生活丧失了希望的人摇摇晃晃地走在深夜的小巷中，他被一个、一个、又一个饮料瓶绊住脚，随后，他终于发现了那个突然出现在小巷角落的黑色贩卖机。在喝下贩卖机里掉出的非卖品饮料后，他看到了这辈子都不曾想象到的景象：无数个小小的金色幻影和粉色的毛团围着他跳跃，他被邀请上一个奇特的机甲，机甲在启动后不仅一下子飞上了半空，驾驶舱外还有一个奇怪的黎博利在哼着节奏劲爆的歌......
在终于降落回地面后，这个深夜突然遇上无数美妙幻景的人突然看到一个红发的萨科塔带着几个人向自己奔来，一边欢呼着一边不知从哪里掏出了纸花筒和苹果派：“老板让我们来送货，请签收，派对开始——！”
Miss.Christine窝在贩卖机的最上面，一边有些嫌弃地用双尾拨开机甲的尾气，一边看着那人的身上逐渐生出名为“快乐”和“幸福”的甜蜜情绪。她对自己的小游戏非常满意。
喵呜！
modules.name: “黑色”贩卖机

modules.description:
As she saw how the buildings thrust through the clouds and towered in the skies, what filled the mind of the Zalak girl, not yet Flametail Knight, was the loftiest red pine back home.
And they hit her heart—a flash of longing, a flash of depression—as she recalled that final swathe of Pinus Sylvestris still standing, only to be razed in a sudden Catastrophe.
Sona had never actually returned to that forest since.
Perhaps that pine was lucky enough to survive the disaster? And maybe, some time next year, the pinecones that fell intact would find a completely new life in the ash-blanketed earth... just as she did.
She had to live on, in the stead of her friends and family who lost their lives to Catastrophe. She had to plant roots and bud in the soil they named Kazimierz. Such notions kept her driven to the present day.
But before she knew it, Sona was shaking her head free of them all. They skipped too many steps—they would only trap her in more regrettable circumstances. She couldn't go on like this. She had to learn to be optimistic. Shape up her act, and perhaps the merchants would give her an out, and employ this little Infected girl to do what handiwork she could.
Soon after, she learned from newspapers and television that Infected, too, could be knights. She was going to find a way in. Still, she wanted to become one just so she could make a living. With no chivalric spirit of old turned life lesson, and no grand visions or hopes, Sona clenched her fist tight.
But the next thing she knew, she was being forced to raise it against fellow Infected who deserved it just as little.
Sona wasn't strong, but she was nimble. She stood out amongst the Infected for it, and was selected by the bankroller of an underground power and sent into the 'cleaning qualifiers.' No weapon in hand, danger surrounding her, and a single fist planted in her foe's face. And they toppled, and Sona won the right to survive another day—but she wasn't happy. She wasn't strong. Taking her opponent down in one blow... it could only be because they were starving, because the evening before, their backer 'tipped' a few knights some bonds to get into a brawl with them.
Sona wasn't happy. She wasn't strong.
Some fawned, telling her if she just dressed up a little, she'd be so cute, so lovely and sweet. Some gushed, telling her if she just went through some proper training, she'd be a terror of the racetrack.
Until one voice told her: 'You've got a tail like a blazing fire.' It caught her off guard.
There was nothing in particular beneath that statement, and it was no more than an ordinary spectator, reveling in the violence, who yelled it.
But it was the first time Sona had ever choked with emotion after a match.
Yes. She'd just realized it. She ought to be like a blazing fire.
modules.name: The Origins of Pinus Sylvestris

modules.description:
Sona keeps complaining she's old, her body isn't light anymore. What could she mean, just a few years ago she was hopping all over the arenas, making the armorless scramble around the whole screwy city! —Wild Mane

She left to help out the Radiant Knight the day before, and she's been awake three straight days, so now she's very sleepy. Also, when you see this message, remember to pay the outstanding balance on your suppressants. —Ashlock

i already notified a messenger. dont count on iwona remembering in time. —Fartooth

IMPORTANT NOTICE: RHODES ISLAND BRANCH OFFICE IS HOLDING A SAUIN PARTY SOON. The Infected kids will be going too. —Flametail

A little liveliness is good for the children, but do you really still have the energy? I haven't seen you physically for two days now. —Ashlock

Oh yeah by the way, yesterday Maria came because she had equipment for us, when she opened the door Greynuty thought you came back Sona, once she realized it wasn't you she —Wild Mane

go on? —Flametail

Tell you in person. —Wild Mane

Sona's busy. Don't pester her. —Ashlock

why exactly does this message board exist? arent inci net comms more convenient? —Fartooth

I came home and saw Justyna stuck on whether or not she should post a new message. It took her ten whole minutes. —Ashlock

ive realized. some things arent appropriate to post on a messageboard everyone can see. —Fartooth

we still have secrets between us? that's no good, we've gotta grill Justyna STAT. —Flametail

its secret. dont let ashlock know. —Fartooth

Hey you're calling Greynuty her nickname again. —Wild Mane

I hope said secret has nothing to do with the brand new autumn windbreaker and Higashi game console you bought behind my back. —Ashlock

shorter. easier to spell. buying the console was sonas call if that helps. —Fartooth

（°Д °） —Flametail

Confiscated. —Ashlock

Ashlock has been trying it on in front of the mirror forever now, where's mine guys? —Wild Mane

Doesn't work good for going fast. I appreciate your kindness guys. Justyna you can have it. —Wild Mane

Does it count as capitulating to the GCC now that I bought these? —Zofia

NOTICE TO USERS: ANY OUTSIDERS USING THIS MESSAGE BOARD MUST PAY TAX. —Flametail

Think you're all away from home right now? Your equipment maintenance is all done. I put it in the storeroom. —Maria

NOTICE TO USERS: NEARL FAMILY IS TAX EXEMPT. —Flametail

Hehe —Zofia

Your efforts are appreciated. —Margaret

ain't no problem. —Flametail

RFC lower height of message board and/or add mechanical arm to Justice. —Justice Knight

EASY. —Closure

HELL NO!! —Wild Mane

just responding to Justyna's question a few days ago. the thing is, we're usually all over the place and too busy to see each other, but this is our home. our home, for us, finally. i want a little something to leave behind here. besides, this has been pretty fun so far. —Flametail

also, did we not pay the electric? —Flametail
modules.name: Their Future

modules.description:
镜头一路抖着追进晨雾弥漫的窄巷，石板路上还残留着夜雨的潮气，羽生萌萌香裹着戏里的粗布羽织，一边小跑一边朝举着麦克风的导演摆摆手：“等我打完招呼再说哦——”
巷口第一个群演是卖煤油灯的老工匠，他黑油油的手掌在围裙上抹了一把，递来一盏修好的灯，萌萌香笑着接过，又郑重地向他道谢；再往前，是刚被选来当群众演员的书店小伙，站在挂着斑驳招牌的门前，他耳根通红地说自己只有一句“是，武士大人”的台词，但萌萌香还是认真地和他排练了好多遍。镜头跟着她穿过拱廊：小店老板娘正熬着杂煮，才掀起锅盖，蒸汽就撞上了镜头，惊得老板娘连声道歉；粗点心店的店员安抚着总想探头上前的小孩们，萌萌香路过店门扮了个鬼脸，大家又都笑了起来。麦克风一次次蹭过屋檐，收进风铃叮咚的响声、店铺的吆喝......整条老街都被收入磁带，吱呀吱呀，慢慢转动。
午后开拍前，萌萌香坐在布景车的后凳上，周围临时招来的车夫、小贩、学徒们围着看她给小女孩扎髻。镜头掠过她颈侧一缕被汗打湿的碎发，然后缓缓拉远，扫过褪色的町屋格子窗、青苔覆盖的石灯笼、如蛛网般横在木屋之间的电线——谁也想不到，几年后这一切会在一场突如其来的争斗中化为废墟。
那天，所有人都只为了一部现在看来稍显稚嫩的影片忙得热火朝天，笑声、讨论声和咔哒咔哒的摄影机声，在锻冶町的每一条砖缝里敲打着节拍。
当天，导演拍下的最后一个镜头，是萌萌香拿着众人为庆祝她杀青而准备的花束，站在河桥上，回身向镜头挥手。夕阳将她的帽檐染出一条金边。背景中，群演们正陆续散去，拖着各自的影子回家。没人急着拆掉那块铺在河面上的跳板，好像明天还会继续拍摄同一场戏。
花絮的画面就定格在这一瞬。此刻的房间里，安静得只剩钟声的回响，羽生萌萌香在沙发里蜷成小小一团。电视屏幕上，刚出道的自己还站在桥上挥手，河水被落日染得像熬透的糖浆。她就这样看了很久，直到画面跳回蓝底的待机界面，才抬手用遥控器将它关掉。房间瞬间暗了下来，只剩窗外一线霓虹微微照亮她摆在窗边的小树，照亮那张有点陈旧的纪念照——像当年橘色夕阳落进木楼窗棂，温柔地拂过她坚定的心。
modules.name: 迟来的纪念

modules.description:
一个再普通不过的午后，吉星和遥坐在舰桥的高台上，吉星百无聊赖地吹着风晃着腿，听着遥在身边轻声哼歌。
“萌萌香小姐，我想回御机了。”
“欸？怎么突然说这个？”
吉星盯着天空中缓慢移动的云朵，有点不好意思地说：“本舰上好玩的东西太少了嘛。虽然有游戏室，但是和御机那些游戏机厅还是没法比。而且我也不能赌钱了，突然感觉生活好没意思啊。”
“你前几天和大家一起看源石虫赛跑的时候可不是这样说的哦？”
“呃，那不一样啦......”吉星挠了挠头，刚刚那片云此时已经游到了自己脑袋正上方，“该怎么说呢？我也去过好多新的地方了，好像就是没什么特别好玩的了。”
吉星突然认真起来，低头掰着手指说道：“小钢珠我打了那么久，感觉也该到十几年之痒的时候了；彩票和刮刮卡太无聊了，没有让我血脉偾张的快感；‘21点’嘛......就得在那种脏兮兮的地下小店里打才有感觉啊！骑士竞技赛我也看过了，有时候看着挺兴奋的，但如果那些骑士打架打得很难看的话，我也会不爽。”
遥听完轻笑出声，“吉星现在看起来很像是炎国古装片里，阅遍世间武功的那种大侠客呢。”
“萌萌香小姐就别笑我啦......难道这片大地就没有什么有新意的、一下子就能让人兴奋起来的游戏吗？唉，没意思，生活好没意思啊！”
“或者找点别的爱好呢？你说的这些总归是伤神伤财的嘛。”
“呜，萌萌香小姐，我剩下的爱好就是听你唱歌了——”
“欸欸？别、别说得这么一本正经啦......那晚上去吃关东煮，然后我再唱给你听？”
“好耶！”
约定好了晚些时候见面，吉星告别了遥。看着逐渐远去的云朵，她的心情突然又好了起来。大概生活总是要这样继续下去的吧，培养一些新的爱好，找一些新的乐子，然后过完剩下的日子。吉星这样想着，走在本舰的走廊里。嘿，不如去博士的办公室里找点乐子？说不定还能偷拍博士睡觉的照片拿去卖点钱玩玩。
吉星这样想着，走进了博士的办公室。
然后她看见了垃圾桶里的这叠宣传单。
modules.name: 可疑的宣传页

modules.description:
Why do people like to drink?
When Rafaela first began her bartending job, the question floated to her mind from time to time.
She can always ask her papá when she has a question. But this is a work thing—Papá usually barely talks to her about his work, so likewise, she'd better not ask him about hers.
And she doesn't want to ask her hermano about it.
Especially not her hermano.
So she'll ask a customer! People are always coming and going in Dossoles, but in just a short time, Rafaela's learned to recognize a lot of regulars, and they all like to talk to her.
According to the person dancing wildly to the jota while calling her 'Rafa' and 'chica' at the top of their lungs, you drink for the color, the mouthfeel, the taste, and for a moment of joy.
But according to the person calling her 'Señorita Silva' while leaning on the bar counter, sluggishly lifting a hand as they sing fado, you drink just to forget and be free from your worries for a while.
'Thanks for asking,' they add more often than not.
Rafaela isn't sure if she comprehended all these answers, but she makes sure to remember every one. It's how it should be, she thinks.
Times change.
As the landship sails, there's a regular thrumming all throughout the hold. Rafaela hasn't gotten used to this noise yet—after all, it's nothing like fowlbeast chirps or beating waves—but she doesn't react badly to it at all.
She's asked another operator before, and now she knows this is how it should be on the ship.
In the landship, music is more varied too, with lots she's never heard before.
Even so, the person who dances wildly while calling her 'Rafa' and 'chica' at the top of their lungs is still there. When she meets this kind of person, she does as they request, and squeezes some of the sweetest fruit juice into their drinks, adding some of the most bracing syrup. But at the same time, she secretly dilutes these flavors until they make for the coolest, most reinvigorating flavors. She gives whoever's drinking it a moment of joy, and all the wake-up they need to bask in that joy.
And there's still the person who calls her 'Señorita Silva' and 'Miss La Pluma' while leaning on the bar counter, sluggishly lifting a hand. When she meets this kind of person, she does as they quietly ask her, and pulls the strongest, most biting bottles from the racks to pour into their glass. But at the same time, she doesn't forget to mix in a little of the finest pedigree, sourced locally from Logroño. She watches them down a glass of bitter drink, but knows the taste left behind won't be totally astringent.
'Thank you,' they say in approval more often than not. Sometimes she nods, but feels strange about it, so other times she just doesn't nod at all.
Of course, this method of mixology isn't entirely described in the Dossoles Guide to Cocktails, but she makes a note of it in there herself.
And she's already given the book away to someone who deserves it. She may not have it anymore, but she's learned it by heart.
Rafaela feels that this way is good.
This is how it should be.
modules.name: Aqua Blue Dawn

modules.description:
Maggy, I got your pictures, thank you. The aurora's so pretty, so... stunning. Sorry I can't find better words. I saw the other material you sent back from Rhodes Island too. That little yellow flower! I never knew flowers that pretty could grow in the extreme north, all the way in the ice deserts! It's unbelievable, really.
You suggested I should 'join the next exploration project as a supporting surveyor,' right? I've given serious thought to it. Not whether to go or not—I still have to stay on the landship at this stage so I can get Oripathy treatment. It's what help I would be if I did go. Mayer's said how under extreme cold conditions, your Soaring Dragon drones get their stability affected. I minored in research filming while I was studying at Ironforge Polytechnic, so I tried installing a set of production lenses on my shield, so it could handle photography and data storage roles at certain temperatures. I should be able to take my shield through more special terrain, compared to using drones, and use it for fundamental defense work. It can sort out the issue of stability, too.
......
Maggy, I admire you, with all my heart. While everyone only has the barest imagining of what such faraway places are like, you've gone deep into them, gotten a taste of all this fascinating scenery, felt the pulse of life. I once went with a survey group into the northern icefields and saw the aurora, and that was when I learned a really important lesson in life: not every place has snowy peaks like Kjerag, and protection like Kjeragandr's, but every place has its own beauty you can't explain with common sense. The Black Flow forests, the Ringed Plains with mountains all around... all these extreme landscapes have nothing to do with the supernatural, really. They're part of Terra in themselves. I can't help but wonder, just how—shallow and narrow everything we know and hear and think and believe about this great land is.
I want to see the aurora again more than anything else. I want to go and see the ice deserts. Not so I can prove anything—just because, well, 'I want to go and see.' Master SilverAsh is right. If we want to protect Kjerag, then we have to know just what kind of world it is we live in.
We can only better defend the homeland behind us if we're brave enough to explore onward. And besides, I have this sort of feeling, like the ice deserts, the poles, all these places full of hidden secrets far away already have a lot of eyes watching them... 
So once I'm ready, Maggy, you can be sure I'll submit my application to the Doctor.
......
I eat... a little bigger, and I sleep more as well, but you don't need to worry, I promise. When it comes work time, I'll get down to it, believe me. I'm sure I'll be able to help you out.

—Extract from comms logs sent to Operator Magallan by Operator Aurora
modules.name: Shield Photography Module

modules.description:
Truth be told, Kowal has a dream. He'd already made the kid's come true.
Once, Maria was viewing her ancestor's portraits by Margaret and Auntie Zofia's sides, listening to them tell legends of Kazimierzian knights of old. She lifted her head and asked her sister: 'Is the armor they wear the same as yours?'
Margaret smiled and shook her head.
Then Maria asked: 'What about the sword?'
Unable to hold back a laugh, Zofia decided they'd pay a visit to Kowal's knight workshop while the weather was still good.
That afternoon, Maria saw Master Kowal hard at work in his shop. He was always a friend to his friends, and on occasion boisterous too.
'If a knight's honor really be measured in a crown, then that crown's going to be made by the Craftsman's Guild,' Kowal laughed, as he picked Maria up.
Maria didn't mind the smell of iron at all. She watched the delighted expressions flit across her sister and aunt's faces as they looked over the weapon, and her eyes shone brilliantly.
Luckier still, she just so happened to be deft at the very thing she was interested in, which raised her spirits.
'She's a jack-of-all-trades, I tell you,' Kowal said, wiping the foam from his mouth. 'Say, remember when we were holding that lone city out on the plains? Remember all that work the old one-eyed boy from the blacksmith's got up to, and we thought he was just some nobody? If it weren't for him, we'd have caved before reinforcements arrived!'
'Of course I remember! How could I forget!' The old knight's face was aglow at the mention of tales of the past, and even his own drunkenness slipped his mind. 'But what're you saying? Maria could match that, no contest!'
Kowal would normally have fired a retort at his old friend out of habit, but as that stretch of the past washed over him, and he remembered the brothers-in-arms they'd lost, he fell quiet. His silence said enough though, and V took a swig of his drink before lowering his voice. 'What d'you think of her, that Maria girl?'
'Me?' Kowal came back to his senses, went briefly blank, then let out a huge grin. 'If Maria'd been around back then, holding the city would've been nothing. Could've even counterattacked! And done it damn well.'
V said nothing. He simply returned his own grin.
For the banished Margaret had come to mind.
Maria had cried for days and nights, even wailing about how she'd go find her sister herself. It was Zofia who soothed her to sleep, and kept her company at home.
Kowal loathed himself for doing an awful job of protecting the Nearl family, and was ashamed of what old man Kirill might've thought. All these years, he'd hardly done any work himself.
Rust. Creeping across the surface of this radiant, beautiful city. Yet the old boys could hardly do a thing anymore.
'I'd give anything to hear those lively sounds a-banging away again. We need that girl's hands...' Kowal mumbles to himself.
'...Too much to drink, methinks?'
'No, like this, you see.'
Kowal sidesteps the question and gesticulates with his hands, as if he's holding a hammer, and the scene outside the tent's a thousand miles of grassland lapping at the white clouds, and the lumber and the stones pile up high amidst the sounds of knocking, forming a grand castle.
Clank—
Ringing through the air.
modules.name: Echo of Craftsman's Guild

modules.description:
This is a dream. Maria can tell.
An unfamiliar host is straightening out their formal attire, ice-cold light shrouding the entire venue, but the night sky is a million miles away, and the superfluous bustle envelops her.
She turns her head, only to see expressionless campaign knights. Their silver armor appears dazzling—they nod to send her their regards. Some elderly people step up, reading out indistinct sentences. She sees the Grand Knight Russell, a hair older than everyone else, the hero in her twilight, under her ceremonial guard's escort, approaching her bearing a shield.
Maria recognizes this shield. Engraved with the crest of the Nearls, wrapped in the banner of the Nearls, it could not be any more familiar to her. Maria knows what this signifies, and she feels a sense of bewilderment. Her uncle didn't want her becoming the Knight Primus, and her sister didn't want to acknowledge the modern knight institution. So what should she do?
Or... what does she want to do?
Maria hurriedly looks around. Her sister's not there. Her auntie isn't there. Uncle Młynar, V, Master Kowal, Marcin, none of them are there. She wants to run, but rationality lashes her to the spot. This is a major occasion. She can't shrink away, even if this isn't how she wanted it.
Nerves and unease momentarily catapult Maria into reminiscence. It's a workshop breathing with sizzling heat, and she's forging a brand new sword for her sister Margaret. V and Master Kowal are bickering as ever—Zofia lovingly wipes her forehead to take off the sweat, and tidies up her disheveled hair. Młynar is in the shade of a tree not far away, silently watching over it all, and on the other side of the street, long since lost to her childhood memories, are her father, mother, and the one who'd left only the shadow of a lance behind at the fringes of her hopes, old Grandpa Nearl...
'From this day forth, you are Knight Primus of the Nearl family.'
Maria accepts the shield, and its solitary weight leaves her lost at sea. She feels as if she's still in that vision. She's still poring over blueprints, operating the furnace. She doesn't want to forge mail to amuse the people, nor lances to slaughter the innocent.
She wants to forge an 'ideal.' An 'ideal' to protect the ones she loves, to become a hero's strength, to brace herself upright, never to dread confusion and solitude.
The clanging of steel on steel still rings in her ears. Engulfing the cheers, engulfing the glory.
'Maria.' A familiar voice softly calls to her.
She lifts her head, and at this moment the clamorous arena holds not a soul in sight.
modules.name: 'Knight Primus'

modules.description: Having hastily finished his dinner, Hohenlohe has just about stepped into his villa's quarters for the night when Carnelian appears behind him without warning. 'What are you doing here so late?' 'You had worries, and I've just seen to them. I'm here to report in, of course.' 'Oh, I see.' A gust of night air blows through the room, mile-long curtains fluttering restlessly. Having left his Spire for the moment so as to smooth out tomorrow's parade, the Count feels the air faintly nip at him. 'Hold on, what made you—no, let me restate. Can you even be that quick?' 'Of course.' 'Really? Well, I'll make one more check, just on the off-chance. Given tomorrow's parade, you—' 'Off-chance? Don't you have faith in me?' Much like one would enrage at a habitually interrupting bodyguard, the Count stomps his feet forcefully. 'How could I have faith? Are you to say an instrument can be so quickly learned? What, did you take up the triangle?' 'You surmise well.' 'Do I now? You plan to show up to my parade tomorrow tinkling on the triangle?!' 'Exactly. And by the way, all triangle lovers take grave offense at your words.' 'You—! You might recall I had every other bodyguard playing music at last year's visits, while you alone stood there doing nothing, making us all look like fools!' 'And you insisted I act like a member of the bodyguards last month, when an envoy came from the next city over. If you'll remember, when he affixed a tapping device under the table, I drew my weapon across his throat by reflex before remembering I was holding a trumpet, not a sword.' 'Carnelian!!' 'I'll be blunt—looking after you takes enough of my energy. I'm certainly not disposed to learn an instrument for you.' 'I don't care! I demand you learn! I demand it!' The Count glares at his unrepentant attendant with all the temper of a small child, ultimately not so furious as to pounce at anything—he simply slams the door as he leaves. But the moment the door latches shut, Carnelian places a firm grip on the dagger at her waist. 'Alright, you behind the curtain. Come out. 'An assassin sent by the diet, I presume? And you really think that once the Count is dead and his cousin succeeds the title in all his ambition, he'll grant the Stadtrat autonomy? 'No. Forget that. Here's a different question. Would you prefera sophisticated death, or one more to-the-point? '...Well, if you won't say anything, can I take that as the dealer's choice?' The assassin barely has time to twitch before the curtain becomes a pair of lips, the bookshelves jaws, and the candles incisors. One massive chomp on their windowside prey is followed by chewing, then a swallow, and finally a mess all over the floor. 'It's over now. Won't you come in?' The Count pokes his head through the door to confirm that all danger has passed, then musters all his courage before entering. 'Very swift to react, and on-point with the improvisation as well. Quite well done.' 'I don't need you complimenting me.' The two of them stare at the villa bedroom, a scene of chaos and scraps and fresh blood, neither breaking the silence. It isn't the first unsuccessful assassination attempt, but all previous ones have taken place at Count Hohenlohe's Spire, which is hardly dilapidated enough to let would-be murderers as far as the sleeping quarters. After a spell, the Count breaks the tension. 'Carnelian.' 'What? I can't exactly use my Arts to clean rooms.' 'And I wasn't expecting you to.' 'Good call.' 'I wanted to ask, are you really not going to learn an instrument?' 'Oh? So you are scared of losing face after all?' 'As if! No, it's no more than a bit of curiosity. You—' The Count's face flushes red. He stammers silently. Eventually, having not said a word further, he turns to flee the bedroom. Carnelian shakes her head. The hyacinths by the head of the bed catch her eye. In front of them lies an implement nominally for self-defense, but hardly useful in practice, save for offering the Count a little mental assurance—a dagger. Though yet to nestle in anyone's flesh, blood has dyed its blade a deep carmine.
modules.name: Hyacinth and Dagger

modules.description: Sargonian has a noun to describe a very particular emotion, 'the pleasant surprise of finding the familiar in somewhere strange.' In this, you can see the significance of the local accent to Sargonians. However, one time, Beeswax made a sudden appearance in a Leithanian restaurant where she seated herself right across the table from her sister, and as Carnelian's hand slowly fell from her in-ear comms terminal, her expression flickered with rare alarm. 'S... Surprise? Heheh...' In a snap, Carnelian shut off her receiver. It wasn't as if Beeswax forgot her sister's advice to keep away from Leithanien. Abashed, she explained that she was just passing through. A paper-thin lie; Carnelian could already imagine which Rhodes Island operator had needlessly put her up to the task. She wasn't especially dismayed, of course. She positively coddled Ankhesena, indulging every anecdote from her journey, their table the picture of love and peace. Meanwhile, in her ear, a very different picture was being painted. 'Boss! Do you copy! The target's about to enter the Arts Circle focus!' 'She was laying low, right?! Did shit go down at the restaurant?!' 'Sis, what's that buzzing coming from your ear?' 'Oh, it's just music. The Leithanians aren't half bad at it. You'd like it.' 'Boss! Are you there?!' Carnelian sighed and got up. 'It's a little noisy, though. Give me a moment to go and adjust it.' The 'music' her sister mentioned caused Beeswax some turmoil. It'd been years since they last met, during which this strange country had clearly changed her sister—for someone accustomed to the most beautiful melodies, would she really like whatever that was? Beeswax clutched her bundle tight, too shy to open it. Carnelian returned, astonishingly quickly. She took off her terminal, finally able to show a relieved smile. 'What about your music, Sis?' 'It's over. I have more important things still waiting for me to sample—' A word from home, to signify an emotion. Fit to describe the soothing, settling look in Carnelian's eyes, as if by some Originium Arts... It blew Beeswax's worries away. At last, she pulled the item of the hour out of her bag—a plain Sargonian sistrum, distinctly out of place in Leithanien. 'Oh! And I thought you'd lost that forever ago! That's the only instrument I can even play.' Jingle, jangle. The warm, rustic sound of home. 'That takes me back. It's what I always soothed you with when you were little. Do you still remember that?' 'Your work must be really important, what you're doing in Leithanien.' 'What? No, I've only been...' 'Remember to stop sometimes, and listen to it, okay? Just sometimes... when you're too busy to reply, and you don't have time to visit home, just listen to it...' Carnelian relented, her gaze turning soft. Alright, I'll remember to write back, and I'll make my way home again as soon as I can, she wanted to say. But she didn't make that promise—it's one she had no idea when she'd be able to keep, if ever. Instead, she picked up the sistrum and gave it a light shake. How very, very curious. Here, in a Leithanian restaurant, she could almost hear the rustling of the leaves on Sargon's trees... She and Ankhesena always liked to call it the forest playing to them. They used to love it.
modules.name: Always Have Your Back

modules.description:
The shoe-shiner trembles as he enters the Bellone famiglia parlor.
He trembles not because this is Bellone territory. He had shined Bernardo's shoes for thirty years, and the man always respected those who respected him. The last time he had stepped into this parlor, it was so that he could offer Bernardo the chance to name his son.
His fear comes from the fact that the one sitting here today is not Bernardo, but his son, Leontuzzo.
He has not heard much about the Bellone heir. All he knew was that the young master had never come to him for a shoe shining.
'My father isn't here at the moment, but you can trust me as you trusted him.'
His words calm him a bit, allowing the shoe-shiner to explain why he had no choice but to come:
His son leads a decent, honorable life, and fell in love with a lady from Columbia. However, that lady was also being pursued by a maniac who didn't take kindly to a rival. Three nights ago, his son was cornered by that maniac and beaten within an inch of his life. He'd sought aid from the courts, but the man belonged to a Columbian famiglia, and his lawyers were easily able to secure a 'not guilty.'
'When I was leaving the courtroom, he stepped in front of me and shoved two banknotes into my pocket. He laughed as he told me it was for my son's medical fees. I...' The shoe-shiner went on, tears streaming from his wizened eyes.
Leontuzzo listens in silence. He knows that if his father were here, he would surely give the old man a pat on the shoulder, acknowledge his suffering, then provide a solution to this. A humane way.
Generally speaking, these things could only be resolved with bloodshed.
But that was not how he does things.
'What is it you wish for, signor?'
'I have no requests, Don Leontuzzo, other than justice for my boy.'
'Justice. Am I to understand that you want this man to feel the same pain your son did?'
'That's right. Nothing more.'
Leontuzzo snaps his fingers, and a red-headed young man steps out from a door to the side.
'Demetri, go investigate the gang behind that guy first.'
'Easy enough, but what comes next?'
'Next... If I'm not mistaken, those Columbian gangs want to sidestep us and cozy up to the local government. Then let's propose sending local 'talents' to the Columbian frontier. Hopefully, every famiglia will enthusiastically agree. Let them send off a few stronzi who should have been exiled long ago.'
The red-headed youth snaps his fingers. 'So we'll ship this guy off too?'
'Exactly.'
'Capisco.'
With that final declaration, the man leaves the room. Leontuzzo turns towards the astonished shoe-shiner. 'This is the justice I can give you. Are you satisfied with it, signor?'
The shoe-shiner quickly catches on, and his gaze turns from astonishment to gratitude.
'Take this.'
'This is...'
'My pistola. Place it by your shoe-shiner, and nobody will cause you trouble.'
'But—'
'Don't worry. I barely use it. Whenever you feel like you can sleep easy again, just give it back to the guard downstairs.'
modules.name: La Punciuta

modules.description:
主驾驶席上，莱昂图索有些紧张，今天是他第一次正式开车上路。
观察左右，调整座椅，调整后视镜，系好安全带，确认档位——完成了这些步骤后，他有些忐忑地看向副驾驶席，那里坐着拉维妮娅，他的教练。直到拉维妮娅点了点头，他才微微松了口气，然后，扭动钥匙，启动引擎。车辆缓缓离开车库，驶入街道。
街上一如既往地下着淅沥的小雨，莱昂图索打开雨刷器，小心地踩着踏板，不敢开得太快。
“莱昂，你开得太慢了，这样练习是没什么效果的。”拉维妮娅作为他学车的教官，对他一如既往地严格。
“你越是提醒我，我越是紧张，拉维妮娅。”莱昂图索紧握着方向盘，认真盯着眼前的道路，甚至连头也没有侧一下。
“是谁今早在餐桌上兴致勃勃地说等德米特里回来，要给他露一手？”
“那是我被面包的热气蒸坏了脑袋。”
说话间，车开到了一个十字路口前，前方的红灯即将转绿，人行道上，几个行人正在通行。然而，几个行人似乎是看到了驶来的车辆上面的标志，立刻低下头，快步走过人行道。
不幸的是，其中一个人走到一半，绊了一跤，摔倒在人行道上。
这时，拉维妮娅看向莱昂图索，眼神像是在问：“现在，你的正确做法是什么？”
“......我该狠狠踩下踏板，冲过红灯。最好溅起一阵水花，把行人吓一跳。”
嘴上这么说着，莱昂图索却放缓了车速，车缓缓停在了人行道前。
摔倒的人此时也爬了起来，向车内的两人微微点头表示感谢之后，快步离开。
拉维妮娅有些欣慰地开口：“如果大部分家族的人能像你一样开车——哪怕只是刚才这点微不足道的事情，我每年要判的案子恐怕都能少十分之一。”
“那些交通规则太繁琐了，老实说，我也不想去记。”绿灯亮起，莱昂图索重新启动了车辆，“不过，我最近越来越理解一件事，我们之所以遵守所谓的规则，并不是因为它们天然存在，而是因为，它们是人们追求公平的过程中发现的不言自明的道理。”
“你说得很不错，莱昂。看来，你对交通规则已经有了非常深入的理解，现在，让我看看你是不是真的记住了。”
“天哪，拉维妮娅，你在这里也要教书吗？”
“毕竟，我答应了你父亲，把我知道的一切都教给你。所以，莱昂，现在汽车侧边这些白线的作用是什么？”
“等等，让我回忆一下......”
叙拉古的雨季总是漫长且沉默，不过至少，此时车内的谈笑声能够让人获得一丝温暖。
modules.name: 时光不再

modules.description:
......The wind. 
I can hear the wind's sound changing. 
It was quiet before, but now it's become noisy.
......
Lots of people... They're here to watch the match. 
My first time competing in the knight tournament. 
This is different from when I was in the underground arena... This is an official match. 
...Different? 
I've become an official Infected Knight, but does this really make a difference compared to before? 
...... 
......Soon. 
There's not much time left. The match will start soon. 
I... 
I know, I will win. 
I will win...... 
...... 

Excuse me, is Miss Justyna Valentine here? We've brought your custom-made equipment! 
Huh, is Miss Valentine not here? 
She... hasn't been seen since noon? What do you mean nobody knows where she is? The match is about to begin, and she's still not back yet? 
This is quite unfortunate. Being late to her debut match will surely leave a bad taste in the fans' mouths. This certainly won't do any favors for Miss Valentine's future career! 
And in addition to that, she's going to need to personally look over her custom equipment, and if she's not here... 
Huh? Wait, what's that sound? 
Hmm... Is that... somebody playing the flute? 

The soft melody of the flute was gently carried along the wind, far, far away. 
Ever higher, ever further away. 
The wind continued to blow, to the place I promised to return to. 
Please, take this tune back with you. 
Please tell everyone. 
That Justyna has finally become a knight. 
But don't tell anyone. 
That Justyna sorely misses her home. 

......
......My goodness, how long have I been here?! 
I shouldn't be spacing out like that! Who has the time to sit around leisurely, playing a bland country tune? 
Well, whatever. 
There's not much time left, I've gotta find Miss Valentine, and fast!
modules.name: First-show Support Set

modules.description:
To the incredible Ms. Justyna,

I'm a loyal fan of yours!
...I'm really sorry, I just don't know how to start this letter off. I've almost filled up the wastebasket with scrapped drafts at this point. In the end, I think that cliche is the only thing I can really write.

This is the first time in my life I'm writing a letter to a hero of mine. You said during an interview that you read every single letter from your supporters, and I know you wouldn't lie!
First, I want to congratulate you on getting the title 'Fartooth,' it's so incredibly cool! I was there for your match with Feather Knight, the sight of you winning without any backup at all touched all of us there! It's only right you were #1 in the season!
Ever since I first saw a match of yours three years ago, I got really into you as a knight. You might not remember, but I was sat in the front row of the grandstand, and the knight who was against you slipped up with a move and almost hurt the audience, but then you blocked it even though you were injured. Among the people you saved, the ones behind you, were me and my family.
Ever since then, you've been an inspirational figure for me. You're a true knight, Ms. Justyna, I'm surer of that than anything. I was still a student then, and if I studied good enough and my grades got better, my family would reward me by taking me to see your matches. I could say you were the one who gave me the drive to keep heading forwards.

I want to become a glorious knight like you so much! Knights would never point their arrowheads at the defenseless, and I don't believe you'd ever use violence against any Knightclub's fans!
The 'Fartooth' Knight Justyna I know doesn't concede even when she's hurt, and never talks down to other knights even in the arena. I, along with your other supporters, don't believe any of that slander against you, so please don't take those irresponsible newspaper reports to heart! We're all looking forward to you returning as soon as you can!
Also, when I heard you say you wanted to start your own Knightclub, I was over the moons! You always ran solo in the past, and sometimes you looked sort of lonely, so it made me and a lot of other fans really worried... In the end, whether you start your own Knightclub, join another one, or stay active as an independent knight, we'll always support you as long as it's your decision, Ms. Justyna!
We hope everything goes well for you!

Your faithful supporter
modules.name: Fan Letters

modules.description:
As evening fell, the crowd receded from both ends of the street, revealing the snow-covered pavement. Greynuty hesitated for a moment before finally taking a step onto it.
'Slippery, very slippery, you could fall.' That was the first thought that popped into her head.
Immediately thereafter, the second thought emerged: 'It might be fun, if I don't fall.'
Through her sunglasses, Greynuty cautiously surveyed her surroundings. The street was long, offering considerable distance for a run-up. It was also deserted, with no one to witness her.
'One, two, three!' Taking a few steps back, she braved the cold wind and sprinted forward, accelerating as she went, then abruptly halted, letting momentum carry her forward in a slide.
She then started running again, heading toward the other end of the long street. One meter, two meters, three meters... The speed of her running and sliding increased with each attempt, and her heart rate accelerated with the rhythm of her sprint, bringing a sense of weightlessness. The lightness of her body felt almost as if she were floating down a flowing river.
The river of time.
'Don't be afraid, try to go faster, we'll catch you.' In a trance, amidst the whistling wind in her ears, she heard a familiar encouragement. Similar scenes awakened from dusty childhood memories. At the end of the road, a couple smiled and opened their arms to her.
So this time, she began to sprint with all her might, only to be brought back to reality by a stone under her foot.
After plunging headfirst into a snowdrift by the roadside, she didn't rush to get up, but instead held her face in her hands. Unsure whether she'd grazed her eyebrow or cheek, she felt a dampness around her eyes.
'Need a hand getting up, Ashley?' A figure blocked the setting sun, reaching out to her.
'How did you end up here?' She placed her hand in hers.
She stood up, brushed the snowflakes off herself, and picked up her sunglasses and hat that had scattered nearby.
'You went out for some beer. But it was getting late and you didn't come back, so I was worried. Had to come out to check on you.'
'*Cough* I'm fine.'
'Don't lie, your eyes are really red.'
'The sun's just too bright.'
'The sun's down.'
'...Thanks for helping me up.' She put her hat and sunglasses back on, covering her reddened eyes and cheeks.
'You're welcome.'
'Oh, actually, there's no point in you arming up like that, Ashley.'
'Why not?'
'That shop on the corner there has a special window. You can't see in from the outside, but you can see out from the inside.'
'So you mean...'
'Yep... chock full of people. I even saw a few of your fans in there.'
modules.name: Outdoor Essential Kit

modules.description:
'Gantt, whatcha all alone for again? Still pissed about them folks?'
'They're from his high school. Ain't happy their teach made him a student too. They just won't drop it—it's driving me insane.'
'Their leader was the last president, right? Put in some rule about only taking students from good families, and kept nitpicking Gantt for his background. Screwed with us so bad we couldn't even study properly? We ended up kicking him out, didn't we? The teacher was so happy his tail was on overdrive the next few days, not that he'd say.
'C'mon, Gantt, no more eatin' alone. We'll eat with you. You missed it, but we kicked their butts up and down the field today. Scared 'em shitless!'
'Just smiled, didn't you, Gantt? Knew that'd cheer you up. No need to hide next time they come mess with you—they'll have to go through us!'
'What? Stop the drill a sec, Gantt, I didn't catch that. You said you wanna treat us to three days meals? C'mon, man, you don't need to be treatin' us to food just for winnin' a game. Three whole days, even? What, you're seriously saying it's that valuable to you? Listen, how's about you check on my refits for me, and we cut it down to two days. Deal?
'Hold on, Gantt, you promised if I checked on your installations you'd write my report for me, and you never did! The teacher damn near plucked my feathers clean the day we had to turn it in! That's one meal you owe me!
'What, I cut class thirteen times and you had to sign me in each time, that's why you dropped the report?'
'Well, then, here's bad news for everyone! We figured for last month's applications we just had to pull the ole' man's heartstrings, get a little more funding, right? But Gantt couldn't pull it off, so that's one less Ultimate Frisbee, isn't it?'
'The ole' man says he's immune to Gantt waggin' his tail now? Dang, that's bad—gah, where happened to the lights? Was it the breakers?'
'What's that smell?'
'Gantt! Your installation's on fire!'
......
'It's out! And I say firefighting's worth at least two meals!'
'Quit apologizin', whatcha sorry for? This place is blowin' up daily, just treat us twice and we're good!'
'Do any other teams deal in food and reports and frisbees like we do? Didn't you come up with this too, Gantt?
'Alright, I get it, the idea of money changing hands between us doesn't sit with you. Relax, okay? Adding some cash to the equation wouldn't change a thing, y'know. But it's fine, yeah? Whatever you're comfortable with.
'So, then, like we said, you check on my equipment here, and I compensate you with—a month of food, two maintenance checkups, a report, and three rounds of Ultimate Frisbee?! Hold on, lemme check my math!
'Huh, what, what? What're you patting my shoulder all serious for?
'You'd still help me without any compensation? And that goes for the entire team? No matter when?
'Because we're the first pile of friends you ever made? Well, hell! You for real, Gantt?'
'...Hold on, who counts their friends in 'piles,' huh? Hahaha! Come on, let's go get ourselves some grub!'
modules.name: 'A Bright Idea Occurs'

modules.description:
On that rainy day, a young traveler came through our door, breathing faintly to us that she wished to shelter from the rain.
It was around that time that the children in the village had fallen sick one after another, and my precious Veitch wasn't lucky enough to be spared. We all muttered how it was some devil's witchcraft silently spreading about, and so we all kept our houses tightly shut. But we didn't have the heart to throw a single frail woman back into the wild in the rainstorm, so we agreed to let her in.
The first moment she laid eyes on Veitch, she sensed something was wrong. She was prudent as we worked through his symptoms with her, and she asked how the village at large was doing, before revealing herself to be a roving doctor.
'This is no Originium Arts; it's an illness. The soil and wellwater is contaminated, and the children are the first to be sick; as the poisoning builds up over time, the adults will come to show symptoms too.'
She opened her suitcase, and mixed a medicine with practiced hands. As she did, she spoke. 'I'm sorry. All I can give myself is a temporary first aid, but the only way to cure an illness such as this is to be away from the contamination's source, and convalesce through medication in the long-term. If possible, I'd ask you to tell all the village that they should move away from here.'
'But this is our home,' my husband said with worry. 'Even if this soil will harm us, where are we going to shelter if we leave here?'
The doctor said nothing more. She worked in simple silence.

The weather had cleared up the next day, and I found the doctor just as she was about to leave. On the door was stuck a wild flower, a kind that grew anywhere. In that instant, a faint memory of someone seemed to match with her in my head.
'I remember you, doctor. I've met you before.'
'I was still in a small town on the outer edge of a nomadic city. You'd make home visits to everyone, and you always secretly handed out fresh flowers to us children... I was behind the curtains watching, I remember seeing from there.'
'That was decades ago by now. My mother caught Oripathy, see and we were driven out... and I've gone from a child to a married woman now, I know you wouldn't recognize me. But, well, you look about the same now, compared to all the way back then.'
I told her how grateful I was for her, from the bottom of my heart, for she cured me of my fever when I was young, and now she'd saved my own child too. Yet the look on her face was at first blank, then became so sorrowful, as if she was close to weeping.
'No, please... don't go on any further. Just treat me as though I'd never visited before.'
modules.name: A Quaint First-Aid Kit

modules.description:
I thought this child would have long since vanished everyone. But when the tip of his tongue touched upon the Herald's gift, and he kept all to himself, was not drowned in the voice of we many, and did not become a lowly Sea Terror, I conceded that this may have changed things.
I was meant to prevent that unfortunate plundering, but I did not do so. I watched as those bandits bared their vice. I hold myself in contempt for this inaction of mine. Even if it was to ensure a qualified test subject, to probe at the possibilities for humanity.
I'm sure the child became aware in time that I could have saved everyone, but one as smart as him has no need to seek answers from me. Yes, he is smart and studious, but he has no reverence for knowledge, nor does he treat it as a simple tool. He seems an uninvolved bystander, examining all he witnesses. Perhaps this is the reason he did not lose himself in his bond to the Herald's flesh. Were he of different birth, he may well have been a scholar of his own school.
Originally, no change seemed to occur in the child's body, to the extent I doubted my own research, thereafter deciding to prolong my observation of him. This lasted until he finally found that group of bandits, and cut the flesh from himself to give to them, inquiring if it was their lives plagued of hunger that led them to do evil, and if upon being ensured a life of warmth and plenty they could renounce that evil—
I thought this child would have long since vanished everyone. But this time, I may well find hope for humanity.
modules.name: Entreaty of the Herald

modules.description:
A great tree begins as a tiny seed. When a new shoot emerges, no one can predict whether it will become a meal for a starving beast or grow into a towering giant with branches reaching to the sky.
Some individuals may be destined for greatness from birth, standing at the pinnacle of their cohort, but natural laws will eventually push all once tiny creations toward a greater destiny in the currents of time.
With enough patience, perhaps one day every sapling will grow into a being even more magnificent than the mightiest tree we can conceive of. Will that day come? Yes, it will. That's why they bear seeds and allow themselves to decay and return to the soil to nourish their offspring, rather than permanently hoarding all the nutrients they take in. This is not an act of pity, but an act of hope.
Now, if we expand this context to the entire ecosystem, rather than confining ourselves to a specific species, what happens? All living things help each other, cultivate the land and the sea, making the entire planet more abundant and creating a better living environment for ourselves and future generations. Yes, the possibility of this outcome is equally present in every last ordinary seed.
...
That's what the plan should have been, prior to certain unexpected events.
modules.name: Caerulorum Semina

modules.description:
水月已获得特别认证许可
根据外勤部门决议
在集成战略行动中以改良策略应对敌人
特别颁发此证章
以兹证明
“放心啦，我没有玩弄食物的坏习惯。”
modules.name: 水月特限证章

modules.description:
Rhodes Island Cafeteria.
'Hello, everyone! Tonight we have a special report on the 'Hidden Singer!' I'm your host, Click! Let's start by interviewing the operator standing right here. Hello, Mina, you must have heard of the 'hidden singer,' right?'
'Uh... not really.'
'It's been causing quite a buzz! The whole thing is so strange. For an entire week, the cafeteria speakers played a song at the same time every morning. But when fans of the song asked around, the broadcast room staff insisted that no one had played any music or sung in there!'
'Ah, I've been up on the scaffold each morning this week, refinishing the wall, so I must've missed it. Shucks, what a shame.'
'Then maybe you can help us, Mina. Based on the accent and lyrics, I'm pretty sure the voice belongs to a Colombian operator! She was singing: Onward! Onward! Dig! Dig! Build! Build! Our city must keep growing!'
'The dust falls in our eyes, as the towers rise—wait, you got me singing along! Haha!'
'Yes, exactly! That's how it goes! Wait, your voice sounds somewhat similar... but they sang with so much more energy!'
'If you don't belt your heart out on the worksite, the foreman'll think you're slacking. But if you ask me who else know this song...'
'—Yes, very suspicious indeed. Mina, you're used to singing at work, and it just so happens that every time this mysterious singing started, you were on the job? I think we'll need to check out your work area.'
The upper platform of Rhodes Island Cafeteria.
'Hello, everyone! Are we any closer to the truth now? So, this is the wall Mina's been working on, right? Wait, what's this I found?!' 'That's my mobile powerbank. I always leave it in place till the job's done.'
'I mean what's on top of it—look! It's a microphone!'
'Oh, that old thing? It's just for fun. Look, you can see the beautiful nomadic city in the distance through the porthole; who wouldn't wanna sing before such a nice view? But my wireless speaker's broken, so no way the sound's making it downstairs.'
'Hmm? Oh!'
With a sudden gasp, Click grabs the microphone. 'Ladies and gentlemen, we've solved the mystery! The hidden singer is—'
Mina looks at the microphone in confusion. It was supposed to connect to the wireless speaker in front of her, but instead—somehow she had connected it to an unfamiliar speaker labeled 'Cafeteria Hall.'
'Ah... was it really me?'
Remembering how she'd sung those corny lyrics, thinking no one could hear, Mina winces and covers her face.
modules.name: Mobile Powerbank

modules.description:
大闹一场之后，那两位义帮元老不甘心地离开了，留下满地狼藉——被脑袋砸坏的木椅，被身体撞碎的窗户，还有那块原本竖在门口的、标志性的“义”字木牌，从中间断成两截，陷在了土里。
“受伤的人去屋里包扎，其他的叔叔阿姨，跟我一起把地面打扫干净吧。万一客人看到这幅景象会被吓跑的。”骋风一边说着，一边率先抓起扫帚，另一只手压着小臂上汩汩流血的伤口。
“喂，小子，你才最该包扎。要不是你帮我挡了那一下，我就该脑袋开花了。”
“就是点小擦伤，我没那么娇气......好好好，小叔，别瞪我，我干完活就去包扎。”
昔日的匪徒们笨手笨脚地开始打扫。如今的“镖局”，人数比做山贼时少了一大半，在一片凌乱中更显凄清。有人拾起那断成两半的“义”字：“我们的义，就要这样丢掉了吗？”
骋风接过那断掉的木牌，叹气不语。义帮已经分裂，镖局生意也不见得会有起色，他至今为止的努力，真的都是对的吗？
“喂，”小叔给了他一拳，“你没做错。是那两个家伙勒索客人有错在先。被他们这么搞下去，以后我们生意都难做。”
“就是啊，我才刚认得几个字，万一镖局黄了，不白学了？！”
“还有那些难记得要死的暗号！”
“别提了，那该死的交通规则害我成天挨罚！谁要让我白记那么一通，我可饶不了他！”
“哈哈，还不是因为你脑袋太笨！”
众人聊起为新生活付出的汗水，镖局里一时充满了欢声笑语。骋风释然地松开了眉头，拍拍脑袋，仿佛要赶走内心的迟疑。
第二天，镖局门口的义字木牌竟重新出现。
“我临时用钉子钉了一下，等有空了就做块新的。”骋风恢复了爽朗的语调。
“不用！我看这样挺别致。你看这‘义’字的上下两半，连得比之前还紧哩！”
“就是，现在不都流行——那叫什么，商标吗？我看啊，这就当做我们镖局的商标好了！”这话引来了一片赞同声。
“真的？那我就去找人把它设计成商标，印在我们的衣服和工具上。所以，叔叔阿姨们，既然是你们自己要求的——以后制服可不许不穿了。”
骋风笑眯眯地说出的话引来了一大片抱怨。学打单子、练武、记账，众人正为镖局走上正轨而忙碌着。
modules.name: 义

modules.description:
The girl doesn't remember how long she was asleep. Her only thought is that the sunshine is too bright, and she hides beneath her blanket in defiance. But the wind blowing through the window brings with it a soothing lemon scent. Upon catching it, she stretches out her head and opens her eyes.
